Python: A high-level programming language used for general-purpose programming.
List: A collection data type in Python used to store multiple items in a single variable.
Loop: A programming structure that repeats a block of code as long as a specified condition is true.
Dictionary: A collection of key-value pairs in Python, where each key must be unique.
Function: A block of code that only runs when it is called, used to organize code into reusable segments.
Class: A blueprint for creating objects, providing initial values for state and implementations of behavior.
Variable: A storage location paired with an associated symbolic name that contains some known or unknown quantity of information.
Exception: An event that occurs during the execution of a program that disrupts the normal flow of instructions.
Tuple: An immutable ordered collection of items in Python.
Import: A way to bring in external code or libraries into your script to reuse code from other modules.
